claim.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to state that something is true, even though it has not been proved
claim.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The group claimed responsibility for the bombings.
Opposition leaders will claim victory if the turnout is lower than 50%.
The product claims that it can make you thin without dieting.
No responsible therapist will claim to cure your insomnia.
I don’t claim to be a feminist, but I’d like to see more women in top jobs.
The girls claim to have seen the fairies.
A letter appeared in ‘The Times’ claiming Fleming as the discoverer of penicillin.
claim.translation[0].definitions[0].note: In more formal English, you say it is claimed that something is true
It has been claimed that he was difficult to work with
claim.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to officially demand or receive money from an organization because you have a right to it
claim.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: If you’re still not satisfied, you may be able to claim compensation.
He should be able to claim the price of the ticket back.
You can claim on the insurance if you have an accident while on holiday.
claim.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to state that you have a right to take or have something that is legally yours
claim.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The majority of those who claim asylum are genuine refugees.
Lost property can be claimed between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m.
claim.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if a war, accident etc claims lives, people die because of it – used especially in news reports
claim.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The earthquake has so far claimed over 3,000 lives.
claim.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: if something claims your attention, you notice and consider it carefully
claim.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: The military conflict continues to claim our undivided attention.
claim.translation[0].note_box[0].section: Following the attack, a man phoned a newspaper claiming responsibility.
Political parties always claim credit for economic growth.
The election results were in and the president was able to claim victory.
This hotel can rightly claim that it has some of the best views on the island.
Some manufacturers falsely claim that their products are environmentally friendly.
They can justifiably claim to be the top team in the country.
claim.translation[0].note_box[1].section: claim
to say that something is true, even though it has not been proved
He claims that he didn’t see anything.
She claims to be a descendant of Charles Dickens.
allege
to claim that someone did something wrong or illegal, although you do not give any proof
It is alleged that he murdered his wife.
Patients allege that the two firms failed to warn doctors about the dangers of taking the drugs over a long period.
maintain
to repeatedly say that something is true, especially when other people do not believe you
He continued to maintain his innocence, even after he was sent to prison.
My mother always maintains that I learned to talk at six months.
insist
to say very firmly that something is true
She insists that Tom was there, although he denies it.
Turkey insists that there is more than enough water in the two rivers for all three countries.
assert
to state that something is true – used especially in formal writing when reporting someone’s opinion
They assert that children work better on their own.
The Environment Minister asserted that one third of the country’s cities had major pollution problems.
contend
to claim that something is true, especially when other people disagree with you
Lawyers contend that his back problems were due to an existing injury, not the accident.
It is possible, as Kennedy contends, that her medical condition is caused by her work.
claim.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a statement that something is true, even though it has not been proved
claim.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: They made claims they couldn’t live up to.
Evidence to support these claims is still lacking.
I make no claim to understand the complexities of the situation.
firms that make false claims about their products
The police denied claims that the men were tortured.
Gould rejected claims that he had acted irresponsibly.
his claim to be the rightful owner of the painting
claim.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: an official request for money that you think you have a right to
claim.translation[1].definitions[1].note: pay/wage claim (=a request from workers for more money)
claim.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Fill in and return the claim form as soon as it arrives.
He lost his claim for unfair dismissal.
All claims should be made in writing.
claim.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: the sum of money you request when you make a claim
claim.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: The insurance company cannot meet (=pay) such enormous  claims.
claim.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a right to do something or to have something, especially because it belongs to you or because you deserve it
claim.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: The Maldives pressed its claim to hold the summit.
Philip feared Edward would lay claim to the Scottish crown.
the competing claims of parents and teachers
A woman who has given a man children will always have a claim on his love.
have a claim on somebody’s time/attention etc
Surely they have a rightful claim on their father’s land?
claim.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: something such as a piece of land that contains valuable minerals
claim.translation[1].note_box[0].section: His claims were later found to be false.
unfounded/unsubstantiated
These claims of discrimination are completely unfounded.
extravagant claims
Some manufacturers make extravagant claims for their products.
competing claims
the competing claims of the political parties
conflicting claims
The reports contained conflicting claims of the number of people killed.
make a claim
He made extravagant claims about the benefits of the diet.
deny a claim
Government officials denied claims that the country possessed chemical weapons.
dispute/reject a claim
The prime minister rejected claims of a disagreement within his party.
support a claim
The court found no evidence to support her claim.
back up a claim
They challenged him to back up his claims with evidence.
accept a claim
Many scientists were reluctant to accept his claims.
challenge a claim
Washington continued to challenge the claim that global warming is partly caused by carbon dioxide.
investigate a claim
Detectives are investigating claims that the two officials took bribes.
claim.translation[1].note_box[1].section: a statement that something is true, even though it has not been proved
It is difficult to believe some of the manufacturer's claims for its products.
a statement that someone has done something wrong or illegal, but that has not been proved
He has strongly denied the allegations of sexual harassment.
something that you say or write that you strongly believe
the assertion that house prices are falling
a strong opinion that someone expresses
Her main contention is that doctors should do more to encourage healthy eating.
claim.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a request or demand for money, or the amount of money asked for
claim.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The developer made a claim against the owner for extra building costs.
There were very large claims for loss of earnings.
The company finally agreed to settle her claim (=pay it) for damages.
claim.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: a request for a payment for damage, theft, injury etc for which you are insured
claim.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Europ Assistance will deal with any claim received from the insured.
This form will be needed should you have to make an insurance claim.
The company’s results included a net gain of $87.3 million from the settlement of insurance claims resulting from the interruption of its operations.
claim.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: a right to have or get something such as land or other assets that belong to you
claim.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: They have no claim to the property.
claim.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: a favourable statement made about a product by its producer that may or may not be true
claim.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: The company has been forced by the Food and Drug Administration to remove ‘no cholesterol’ claims from its labels.
claim.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to officially request, demand, or receive money from an organization
claim.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The new rules mean young people between 16 and 18 can no longer claim unemployment benefit.
Alcan claimed damages for the losses that resulted from the government cancelling the project.
claim.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to request money for damage, theft, injury etc for which you are insured
claim.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: Can you claim on your household insurance if the tiles on your roof are stolen?
claim.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: to state that you have a right to something or to take something that belongs to you
claim.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: They wanted to expand the golf course on land that Indians had claimed.
